factorialAsDouble

public static double factorialAsDouble(int n)

factorialAsDoubleIncludeDivisor

public static double factorialAsDoubleIncludeDivisor(int n,
                                                     double divisor)
Computes n! as a double (to provide extended range over a long). We include the divisor here since n! hits with n at about 340. So if there is anything the result would have been divided by, we include it here, thus extending the range of n the function is suitable for.

Parameters:
n -
divisor -
Returns:

gammaOfArgOn2Plus1

public static double gammaOfArgOn2Plus1(int d)
Computes gamma(d/2 + 1) See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gamma_function for description of the analytical result for d odd. For d even, we have gamma of an integer, which is equal to (d/2)!

Parameters:
d -
Returns:

gammaOfArgOn2Plus1IncludeDivisor

public static double gammaOfArgOn2Plus1IncludeDivisor(int d,
                                                      double divisor)
Computes gamma(d/2 + 1)/divisor See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gamma_function for description of the analytical result for d odd. For d even, we have gamma of an integer, which is equal to (d/2)! We include the divisor here since the gamma(d/2+1) hits Inf with d just over 300. So if there is anything the result would have been divided by, we include it here, thus extending the range of d the function is suitable for.

Parameters:
d -
divisor -
Returns:

digamma

public static double digamma(int d)
                      throws java.lang.Exception
Compute digamma(d). Stores previous calculations to speed up computation here, though some precision may be lost because we're adding in larger numbers first.

chiSquareCdf

public static double chiSquareCdf(double x,
                                  int k)

Return the value of the cummulative distribution function of the chi-square distribution, evaluated at x, for k degrees of freedom.

Note that this relies on our approximation of the error function, which is the limiting part of the accuracy. Testing against values produced by octave indicates this is accurate to 5-6 decimal places.

Parameters:
x - value at which to evaluate the CDF
k - degrees of freedom (must have k>0)
Returns:
chi squared CDF evaluated at x given k degrees of freedom
See Also:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chi-squared_distribution}

lowerIncompleteGammaFunctionOfArgsOn2

public static double lowerIncompleteGammaFunctionOfArgsOn2(int s,
                                                           double x)
Return the value of the lower Incomplete Gamma function, given arguments s/2 and x/2. We assume postive integer parameter s (s could be complex in general, with positive real part, but we restrict it to real and integer for this method). We make the evaluation using a recurrence relation, which terminates at s/2 = 1 or 1/2 (i.e. s = 2 or 1)

Parameters:
s - for parameter s/2 to lower incomplete gamma
x - for value x/2 to lower incomplete gamma
Returns:
value of lower gamma incomplete function
See Also:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Incomplete_Gamma_function}

erf

public static double erf(double x)
Return the value of the error function at a given x. We approximate the error function using elementary functions as described at the link below (quoting Abramowitz and Stegun). This approximation is quoted to have maximum error 1.5e-7 (and indeed this appears to be the case in comparison to values produced by octave).

Parameters:
x - value at which to evaluate the error function
Returns:
erf(x)
See Also:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Error_function#Approximation_with_elementary_functions}, Abramowitz, Milton; Stegun, Irene A., eds. (1972), "Handbook of Mathematical Functions with Formulas, Graphs, and Mathematical Tables", New York: Dover Publications, ISBN 978-0-486-61272-0

normalPdf

public static double normalPdf(double x,
                               double mu,
                               double sigma)
                        throws java.lang.Exception
Compute the probability density function (PDF) of an observation x, given the mean mu, and the standard deviation sigma, given that the observations follow a univariate normal distribution.

Parameters:
x - observation
mu - mean of distribution
sigma - standard deviation (not the variance)
Returns:
PDF value
Throws:
java.lang.Exception - when sigma < 0

                        throws java.lang.Exception

Parameters:

Returns:
CDF value
Throws:

normalPdf

public static double normalPdf(double[] x,
                               double[] means,
                               double[][] covariance)
                        throws java.lang.Exception
Compute the probability density function (PDF) of a vector of observations x, given the means, and the covariance of the variables, given that the observations follow a multivariate normal distribution

Parameters:
x - observations
means - means of each variable
covariance - covariance matrix
Returns:
PDF value
Throws:
java.lang.Exception - when the lengths of x and covariance do not match, or if supplied a non-square matrix, or if the covariance is not symmetric or not positive-definite.

normalPdf

public static double normalPdf(double[] deviationsFromMean,
                               double[][] covariance)
                        throws java.lang.Exception
Compute the probability density function (PDF) of a vector of observations x, given the deviationsFromMean of x, i.e. (x - \mu), and the covariance of the variables, given that the observations follow a multivariate normal distribution

Parameters:
deviationsFromMean - x - \mu
covariance -
Returns:
PDF value
Throws:
java.lang.Exception - when the lengths of deviationsFromMean and covariance do not match, or if supplied a non-square matrix, or if the covariance is not symmetric or not positive-definite.
